source.raw_text:
The Kneeling Ab Wheel Rollout primarily targets your core (rectus abdominis, obliques, transverse abdominis) for anti-extension, while also engaging your lats, pecs, triceps, shoulders, and glutes for stability and control as you extend and return. The movement pattern is an anti-extension exercise, forcing your core to resist spinal flexion (arching) as you roll out, and then contract powerfully to pull the wheel back in, working eccentrically and concentrically through a large range of motion. [1, 2, 3, 4]  
Muscles Worked: 

• Primary Movers/Stabilizers: 

    • Rectus Abdominis: The "six-pack" muscles, working hard to prevent your back from arching (anti-extension). 
    • Obliques (Internal & External): Stabilize the torso and prevent sideways tilting or rotation. 
    • Transverse Abdominis: The deep core muscle, crucial for spinal stability. 

• Secondary/Assisting Muscles: 

    • Latissimus Dorsi (Lats): Assist in pulling the wheel back and stabilizing the shoulders. 
    • Pectoralis Major (Pecs): Engage to help control the arm extension. 
    • Serratus Anterior: Helps protract the shoulder blades. 
    • Glutes & Hamstrings: Keep hips stable and prevent sagging. 
    • Triceps & Shoulders: Stabilize the arms and shoulders in the extended position. [1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 7, 8]  

Movement Pattern: 

1. Starting Position: Kneel on the floor, hands on the wheel, arms extended, abs tight, back flat. 
2. Eccentric Phase (Roll Out): Slowly roll the wheel forward, extending your arms and hips, maintaining a rigid, straight line from knees to shoulders (like an extended plank). This is the lengthening (eccentric) phase, where the core resists gravity. 
3. Isometric Hold (Optional): Pause at the furthest point you can control without your lower back sagging. 
4. Concentric Phase (Roll In): Engage your abs and lats to pull the wheel back to the starting position, overcoming gravity. [1, 4, 6, 9]  

Key Technique: 

• Control is key: Avoid letting your lower back arch; the core does the work to prevent extension. 
• Slow and controlled: Focus on the eccentric (out) and concentric (in) phases, not speed. 
• Start small: Begin with shorter rollouts and gradually increase range as strength improves. [1, 2, 4, 5, 6]  


**Citations:**
